channel.title: TGaceAllStories
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from TGaceAllStories, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: My college-age kids inherited $300K from a 401(k). What should they do with this money?
item.description: “This money is likely to be saved for the purchase of homes in 10 years or so.”

item.title: My friend cosigned a loan for a BMW, but the driver defaulted. They’re both on the hook for $5K. What happens now?
item.description: “The driver thinks he should be compensated $1,500 for the tires he’s still paying for.”

item.title: Here’s what’s worth streaming in December 2025 on Netflix, Hulu, HBO Max and more
item.description: ‘Stranger Things’ finally wraps up on Netflix, ‘Fallout’ is back with a new season on Amazon and Taylor Swift takes over Disney+

item.title: ‘It’s expensive feeding and housing a family of 7’: I’m 41 with $46K in credit-card debt. Do I raid my $1.2 million IRAs?
item.description: “I bring in $7,200 a month from my pension and disability benefits.”

item.title: AI could be revolutionary, but don't ‘lose your diversification,' this wealth advisor says
item.description: AI's impact has yet to be fully realized and investors shouldn't put all of their eggs in one basket, according to Eric Diton of The Wealth Alliance.

item.title: An industry focused on death faces an existential crisis

item.title: Top Wall Street analysts recommend these dividend stocks for stable income
item.description: TipRanks' ranking service discusses three dividend-paying stocks, including ConocoPhillips and International Business Machines.

item.title: These cheap stocks should have a big 2026, Jefferies says
item.description: Jefferies singled out Lattice Semiconductor and Entergy as two stocks that are likely to see their earnings and sales growth accelerate in 2026.

item.title: Fed hawks and doves are battling over December rate cuts — watch these clues to see who wins
item.description: Stocks and bonds will react to new data on job openings, wages and labor market perceptions.
